intro: Paepalanthus succisus, commonly known as the woolly puya, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Bromeliaceae family and is characterized by its rosette of thick, woolly leaves that store water. The plant produces striking orange or red flowers that bloom in late summer. It thrives in high-altitude environments with cool temperatures and well-drained soil. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is often cultivated in botanical gardens.
